Local opinion: Hensley supports governor on abortion restrictionsJames Bennett
 |  The Daily HeraldGov. Bill Lee told the Republican caucus last week that pro-life abortion legislation would be the most important work he would do in Nashville, state Sen. Joey Hensley said Thursday.Surrounded by GOP members of the Senate and House, including Hensley, the governor revealed that he wants to enact some of the strictest abortion laws in the country. Those restrictions would include banning women from undergoing the procedure once a fetal heartbeat was detected.“The governor became very emotional as he introduced his plans,” said Hensley, noting that Lee paused to choke back tears during his comments. “He cares very much about the unborn and thinks this is the best thing he can do as governor. He said it’s the most important bill he’ll ever push as governor.“Short of banning abortion completely, which we cannot do because of Roe v. Wade, I agree with him. I have been trying to protect the rights of the unborn essentially since I joined the legislature and have sponsored several bills to restrict it,” the senator added.Last year, a bill restricting abortion passed in the House. It stalled in the Senate amid opposition from Lt. Gov. Randy McNally, who worried about courts throwing it out as unconstitutional.“This legislation, while not completely drafted at this point, will pass,” Hensley said. “We probably will have the most complicated abortion law in the country.”Lee also said he wanted to ban abortion for those seeking to end pregnancies because of the gender, race or disability of the fetus. The proposed legislation would require an ultrasound before an abortion, which is not required in the state now.“We’re taking a monumental step forward in celebrating, cherishing and defending life,” Lee said. “I’m proud to be joined by members of the General Assembly who have helped lead the way in this important effort.”The Republican from Hohenwald said he has been on board for nearly two decades. Hensley was elected to the state Senate in 2012 after serving in the House from 2002-2012.“I have sponsored a lot of pro-life legislation,” said Hensley, who is a medical doctor. “In 2009, I sponsored a bill that would take state funding away from Planned Parenthood. I sponsored legislation that prevented abortion after 20 week, if the fetus is viable. I am a pro-life legislator and person. We should protect the unborn.“I just think when the baby is conceived, society should be protecting the unborn, not making options for abortion.”Hensley noted that he has adopted three children and said adoption remains the best alternative for women who do not want or are not ready for children.“Millions of children have been aborted over the years, and there’s a lot of people who want children and can’t have them,” Hensley said. “Accidents do happen, but we should be obligated to protect them. I am in favor of as few abortions as we can possibly have.”I asked Hensley about the social consequences of restricting abortions. For example, would limits on abortion cost the state more in welfare payments and social programs for struggling single mothers and families?Women had nearly 8,636 induced abortions in Tennessee in 2017, according to the Tennessee Department of Health. The number fell from 14,245 in 2008.“There’s a lot of private organizations that can help expectant mothers,” Hensley said. “If they do not want to keep it, there are lots of people who want to adopt infants. If they want to keep it, we have a lot of services from the state to assist. We have money available for child care. There’s a lot of entities that can help women if they need it.“Yes, I understand the other side of the issue. I just believe in protecting life from unborn babies to the elderly and everywhere in between.”◆◆◆James Bennett is editor of The Daily Herald.
